title: 113_hr1144
content: The Act is titled the "Alabama-Coushatta Tribe of Texas Equal and Fair Opportunity Settlement Act". Congressional findings and policy declaration are included in the Act. Congress finds and declares the policy of promoting tribal self-determination, economic self-sufficiency, and supporting the resolution of historical claims. Sam Houston, a leader in the Texas Revolution, established friendly relations with tribes and protected their lands. The United States affirms the rights of tribes, including the Alabama-Coushatta Tribe, to free and undisturbed use of their aboriginal lands. The Alabama-Coushatta Tribe holds aboriginal title to land in southeastern Texas, which has been illegally trespassed upon, depriving them of economic opportunities. The United States Court of Federal Claims ruled in June 2000 that the Tribe retains aboriginal title to 5.5 million acres of land, with the US responsible for their loss of use of over 2.85 million acres. In October 2002, the Court adopted a compensation sum of Two Hundred Seventy Million Six. The Alabama-Coushatta Tribe seeks $270,600,000 in economic damages from the United States. They have a lawsuit pending in the Eastern District of Texas for failure to fulfill fiduciary duty. The Tribe is willing to waive their rights to aboriginal lands in exchange for Congress restoring their Federal status. Congress is urged to restore the Federal status of the Alabama-Coushatta Tribe to empower them economically. The Tribe is willing to give up aboriginal rights in exchange for improved self-sufficiency. This legislation aims to provide economic development opportunities to the Tribe in line with other recognized Indian tribes. If Congress does not act, the Tribe will pursue their land claims through the courts. The Alabama-Coushatta Tribe seeks economic empowerment through restoration of Federal status. Legislation aims to provide fair economic opportunities and resolve land ownership disputes in Texas through court process. The Alabama-Coushatta Tribe seeks economic empowerment through restoration of Federal status, aiming to resolve land ownership disputes in Texas through court process. Additionally, the legislation aims to protect the Tribe's aboriginal title and insulate the Federal Government and taxpayers from potential liability. The Alabama-Coushatta Tribe seeks economic empowerment through restoration of Federal status, aiming to resolve land ownership disputes in Texas through court process. Section 207 of the Alabama-Coushatta Tribes of Texas Restoration Act is deleted to restore economic development opportunities. The United States and the Tribe will file a motion for entry of final judgment in pending litigation within six months. Prior transfers are approved, and claims and aboriginal title are extinguished. Approval and ratification of prior transfers of land or natural resources within Texas by the Alabama-Coushatta Tribe, extinguishing aboriginal title. The approval and ratification of a transfer of land or natural resources by the Alabama-Coushatta Tribe of Texas extinguishes any aboriginal title and claims against the United States or the State of Texas. Any interest or right in land or natural resources approved and ratified by the Alabama-Coushatta Tribe of Texas is extinguished upon transfer. Personal claims of individual Indians are not affected, and lands held in trust by the United States for the tribe remain unchanged.
